I would highly recommend "White Night" (2007) to you as a movie fan who enjoys stories about perseverance and determination.

This movie follows the story of Tommy, an unemployed mechanic who spends most of his time in a bar called "Trees Lounge" in a small blue collar town.

Tommy seems to always be thinking, "If only X then I could stop drinking".

Despite his struggles with alcohol addiction, Tommy is determined to turn his life around and begin anew.

This determination ultimately leads Tommy to take matters into his own hands and try to solve the mystery surrounding the murder of a pawnbroker in a remote town.

As Tommy begins his investigation, strange things happen. Very strange things.

Strange enough to test (and then break) the very fabric of reality itself.

Despite these challenges, Tommy perseveres and continues to investigate until he finally solves the mystery surrounding the murder of the pawnbroker.

Based on your preferences, here are a few recommendations:
- "Blow Out" (1981) - This is Paul McCartney and Wings live on stage in a concert that is destined to live forever!
- "Providence" (2010) - After Peter Parker is bitten by a genetically altered spider, he gains newfound, spider-like powers and ventures out to save the city from the machinations of a mysterious reptilian foe.
- "Rockshow" (N/ A) - In 1975 and 1976 Paul McCartney and Wings undertook the epic Wings over the World tour, the largest scale tour they would ever undertake as a band. From this tour came both the legendary  "Wings over America" triple live album and the concert film  "Rockshow". Although filmed on this tour at the enormous Kingdome in Seattle,  "Rockshow", originally a cut down version of the concert, was not premiered until November 1980 in New York and April 1981 in London.

  * "Passion" (2011) | Plot: The time is the Russian Revolution. The place is a country burdened with fear - the midnight knock at the door, the bread hidden against famine, the haunted eyes of the fleeing, the grublike fat of the appeasers and oppressors. In a bitter struggle of the individual against the collective, three people stand forth with the mark of the unconquered in their bearing: Kira, who wants to be a builder, and the two men who love her  - Leo, an aristocrat, and Andrei, a Communist.
In their tensely dramatic story, Ayn Rand shows what the theories of Communism mean in practice. We the Living is not a story of politics but of the men and women who have to struggle for existence behind the Red banners and slogans. It is a picture of what dictatorship  - of any kind  - does to human beings, what kind of men are able to survive, and which of them remain as the ultimate winners. What happens to the defiant ones? What happens to those who succumb? Who are the winners in this conflict?

Based on your preferences for memoir-style stories with mistaken identities, I would recommend watching "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid" (1969) directed by George Sidney. This movie tells the story of Butch Cassidy, a notorious outlaw who robbed banks across the American West during the late 1800s to early 1900s.

The story follows Butch Cassidy, along with his band consisting of several other notorious outlaws such as Harry Longabaugh, William Bonner, and Johnnie Ruffler, as they rob several banks throughout the American West during the late 1800s to early 1900s.

The story also follows Butch Cassidy's two teenage sons, Joseph "Butcher" Cassidy III (played by Patrick McGoohan) and William "Kidman" Cassidy IV (played by Richard Pryor) as they grow up and come to blows with one another.

Based on your preference cues, I would recommend two movies that fit your criteria.

First, "The Tell-Tale Heart" is a classic horror movie from 1843. The story centers around a man who becomes obsessed with the sound of his own beating heart. As he becomes increasingly paranoid and unstable, he ultimately commits murder to silence the constant noise in his head.

Second, "Emma" is a romantic comedy from 1815. The story revolves around a housekeeper named Emma Thatcher who is sent by her neurotic, pretentious mother to live with a jolly, vulgar psychiatrist and his eccentric extended family. As Emma becomes increasingly involved with the therapist's household, she begins to develop feelings for the therapist himself. However, as Emma tries to navigate her complicated feelings for both the therapist and his family, she ultimately discovers that true love can never be truly broken.
